newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Sri Lanka delays privatisation of two estate firms.
newsitem.headline: Sri Lanka delays privatisation of two estate firms.

text.p: Sri Lanka has delayed privatisation of two estate firms in which the government was to sell a strategic holding this week on the stock exchange, a senior government official said on Monday.

"Sale of 51 percent stakes in Namunukula Plantations and Malwatte Plantations, which were to be made on the stock exchange on Monday and Wednesday, have been put off for later this month," said Mano Tittawella, director general of the Public Enterprise Reform Commission (PERC).
Tittawella declined to give reasons for the delay.
Sri Lanka sold a 51 percent stake in state-owned Maturata Plantations at a premium last week.
The 51 percent equity stake, introduced at a minimum price of 30 rupees a share, was bought by the Employees' Trust Fund, a state-managed gratuity fund, at 45.75 rupees per 10-rupee share.
The sale of Maturata, Namunukula and Malwatte are part of the government's privatisation programme in which it is selling controlling interests through the stock exchange.
Six plantation firms are already trading on the Colombo Stock Exchange.
